source.author: Entwisle, T.J.
source.title: Conifers (Pinophyta)
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 2. Ferns and Allied Plants, Conifers and Monocotyledons
source.citation: From: Entwisle, T.J. (1994). Conifers (Pinophyta). In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 2. Ferns and Allied Plants, Conifers and Monocotyledons. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Outer side of leaves rounded, stem appearing rounded; cone with columella sometimes angular but not lobed
Outer side of leaves keeled, stem appearing angular (more evident in dried specimens); columella in cone 3-lobed or with 3–4 separate parts
Cones never with warts; cone scales thin, separating to base; straight tree with single trunk, to 20 m high
Cones usually slightly to profusely warty; cone scales thick, fused at base
Cones with or without scattered warts; straight tree with single trunk, generally 5–15 m tall
Cones entirely covered with small, resinous warts; small stunted tree, trunks often several, generally less than 5 m tall
Cones smooth, ovoid, distinctly longer than broad; alternate cone scales much larger, evenly tapered to apex
Cones smooth or wrinkled, ovoid to globose; alternate cone scales larger,  narrowing abruptly toward apex
Cone drying blackish, wrinkled or not wrinkled; cone scales more or less narrowing upwards, with small sharp projection near apex
Cone drying brown and wrinkled; alternate cone scales widening upwards, with bold, broadly conical dorsal protuberance
